column1: Boil water advisory for East Bank of Orleans Parish
on Mon, Oct 8, 2012 at 1:20 PM
PRECAUTIONARY BOIL WATER ADVISORY ISSUED FOR THE EAST BANK OF ORLEANS PARISH

NEW ORLEANS, LA—Sewerage and Water Board and the state Department of Health and Hospital officials are warning the residents of the East Bank of Orleans Parish not to drink, make ice from, brush teeth, bathe or shower, prepare or rinse food with tap water unless it has been properly disinfected until further notice.

A momentary loss of 25-cycle power at about 8:30 a.m. at the main water plant brought water pressure to low levels throughout the eastbank of the city. Out of an abundance of caution, residents are advised that the quality of the water may be unsafe due to bacteriological contamination. Therefore, the Sewerage and Water Board of New Orleans in conjunction with DHH has issued a BOIL WATER ADVISORY effective Monday, October 8, 2012 for the entire east bank of the City of New Orleans. Residents may expect the boil advisory to continue until water quality testing has proven the safety of the water. This does not affect Algiers.
State officials are cautioning users of the water system to disinfect their water before consuming it or using it for food preparation by the following means:

Boil water for one full minute in a clean container. The one-minute starts after the water has been brought to a rolling boil. If there is a flat taste, it can be eliminated by shaking the water in a bottle or pouring it from one container to another.
This boil water advisory will remain in effect until further notice.

column1: <div class="" withRelated right"" id=""WNStoryBody""><span id=""WNStoryDateline"">BOSSIER PARISH, LA (KSLA) -
A boil advisory has been issued for the Dogwood subdivision in Bossier Parish.
Consolidated Waterworks/Sewerage officials say their water system lost pressure after a power outage Monday morning.
Officials say they have issued a boil advisory as a precaution for the Dogwood subdivision with the exception of units 13 through 16 in the Dogwood South subdivision.
It is recommended that all consumers disinfect their water before drinking it, making ice, brushing teeth, or using it for food preparation.
Residents should boil water for one full minute in a clean container.
They the boil advisory will remain in effect until further notice.

All residents advised to boil water
<div class=""vf-widget vf-share-bar-square"" data-button-view=""false"" data-show-counters=""false"" data-show-labels=""false"" data-show-total=""false"" data-widget=""sharebar"">
MASCOTTE, Fla. - The City of Mascotte is under a precautionary boil water until further notice due to a loss in system pressure, officials said.
Officials said customers are advised that all water used for drinking, cooking, making ice, brushing teeth, or washing dishes be boiled. A rolling boil of one minute is sufficient.
Bottled water may be used as an alternative, officials said.
City workers are trying to resolve the problem, officials said.

>

    • The city of Daingerfield issued a boil water notice effective Sept. 29. City Secretary Heide Edmonson said a fire hydrant was damaged by a vehicle, causing a break in the line.

    ""To ensure the destruction of all harmful bacteria and other microbes, water for drinking, cooking, and making ice should be boiled and cooled prior to use,"" Mrs. Edmonson said. ""The water should be brought to a vigorous rolling boil and kept at that boil for two minutes.

    ""In lieu of boiling, you may purchase bottled water or obtain water from some other suitable source during this boil water notice.""

    Mrs. Edmonson said when it is no longer necessary to boil water, the city will notify residents that the water is safe for consumption.

    For questions or further information, call the Morris County Sheriff's Office at 903-645-2232.

TAMA, Iowa — A boil order has been issued until further notice for Tama residents.
Officials said the city’s water has experienced low pressure due to multiple water main breaks.
Residents are asked to conserve water until further notice, and boil water until tests show that water is free from bacterial contamination and safe to drink.

Residents should let water boil for one minute and cool before using. They should use boiled or bottled water for drinking, making ice, brushing teeth and food preparation until further notice. Boiling kills bacteria and other organisms in the water. Untreated water can be used for bathing and similar purposes.

With all bacteria tests from Lakeview Park being negative, the Boil Water Advisory issued Monday for the area is cancelled, Roanoke Rapids Sanitary District officials said.
Anyone with questions can contact the Roanoke Rapids Sanitary District Water Treatment Plant at 252-537-3319.

District CEO Dan Brown said he never believed there would be any contamination, but the advisory was more of a precaution. His department was abiding by State Department of Environment and Natural Resources guidelines that said anytime there is low or negative water pressure there is a chance of bacteria growth, and that chlorine stops the growth.
His department increased chlorine since the event.
The advisory was necessary after an 18 feet long section of 12-inch transmission main split at the Water Treatment Plant at 12:10 a.m. Monday.

“We put up about 150 notices in places we knew had low-water pressure,” Brown said. “The Rapids Street tank drained completely within 30 minutes after the line break. Anytime a public water supply system water pressure is negative, a “boil water advisory” is mandated by NCDENR Public Water Supply rules.”
According to Brown, service was returned by 6 a.m. Monday, but some customers continued to call in outages because their lines were drained.

Boil advisory continues through Wednesday for customers affected by water main break
A 48-hour water boil advisory continues until 3 p.m. Wednesday, Oct. 10, following a water main break in the Helmbright Drive area in Gahanna.

A 48-hour water boil advisory continues until 3 p.m. Wednesday, Oct. 10, following a water main break in the Helmbright Drive area in Gahanna.

City of Gahanna's public information manager Brian Hoyt said the Oct. 8 break interrupted and reduced water pressure to a number of residents including those on Harmony Drive, Helmbright Drive, Beaverbrook Drive and Harmony Court.

Water division crews were dispatched to assess the damage and made the necessary repairs that affected about 65 homes.

Hoyt said the city apologizes for the inconvenience caused by the line break.

Customers affected by the problem received a CodeRED phone call and door hanger notes were left at residences.
